ygData.subject: Re: Some questions from beginner in NEAT
ygData.msgSnippet: I know people have combined NEAT with BP in the past.  For example, Chris Christenson had some success with it, but I m not sure he s still reading this group.

I know people have combined NEAT with BP in the past.  For example, 
Chris =
Christenson had some success with it, but I'm not sure he's 
still reading =
this group.

In any case, the number of generations (and hence the length o=
f 
time) it takes to solve a problem depends on problem difficulty, so 
it'=
s difficult to give an accurate estimate, but 7 hours is probably 
a reason=
able expectation for the problem you cite.  

In fact, supervised classific=
ation problems tend to be faster than 
control problems since they don't in=
volve a domain simulator, so you 
can expect it to be possibly a lot faster=
.  However, if you use BP 
you have to factor in the time that adds to each=
 evaluation, 
depending how you fold it into your procedure.

I'm also gues=
sing you will not need two hidden layers of 8 hidden 
nodes each to solve y=
our problem.  NEAT usually discovers that it 
takes a lot less than you exp=
ect to solve problems that seem like 
they should be difficult.

Finally, N=
EAT has been applied to real world industrial problems in 
simulation, but =
I'm not sure if it's been literally used in e.g a 
real factory or somethin=
g like that.  But a 300 instance 
classification sounds fairly straightforw=
ard. 

ken
